name: DNS
description: Domain Name System (DNS) translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses. It operates primarily over UDP port 53, switching to TCP for zone transfers and large responses.
key_topics: DNS query types: Recursive and Iterative
DNS record types: A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, NS, PTR, SOA
DNS hierarchy: Root servers, TLD servers, authoritative servers
DNS caching and TTL (Time To Live)
Configuring Cisco router for DNS lookups
DNS security concerns (cache poisoning, DNS hijacking)
common_misconceptions: Training materials often state DNS always uses UDP. Cisco documentation clarifies DNS uses TCP for zone transfers (AXFR/IXFR) and when response size exceeds 512 bytes
Many resources oversimplify recursive vs iterative queries. Cisco config guides explain that client-to-resolver is typically recursive, while resolver-to-nameserver is typically iterative
Third-party books frequently confuse A records with PTR records. A records map names to IPv4 addresses (forward lookup), while PTR records map IP addresses back to names (reverse lookup)
Common error: disabling 'ip domain-lookup' globally when only wanting to disable domain lookup for typos in CLI. This breaks legitimate DNS functionality
